qas.question: What year did the government start to build new deep shelters?
How many people were the new shelters going to hold?
What helped cut down time standing in the queue for shelters?
Which two groups help improve life in the shelters?

answers.text: British Red Cross and the Salvation Army

qas.question: What kind of trains provided food in the shelters?

context: Public demand caused the government in October <a0_0>1940<a0_0/> to build new deep shelters:189–190 within the Underground to hold <a1_0>80,000<a1_0/> people but were not completed until the period of heaviest bombing had passed. By the end of 1940 significant improvements had been made in the Underground and in many other large shelters. Authorities provided stoves and bathrooms and <a4_0>canteen<a4_0/> trains provided food. <a2_0>Tickets<a2_0/> were issued for bunks in large shelters to reduce the amount of time spent queuing. Committees quickly formed within shelters as informal governments, and organisations such as the <a3_0>British Red Cross and the Salvation Army<a3_0/> worked to improve conditions. Entertainment included concerts, films, plays and books from local libraries.
